STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 20, 2019
Jacquelyn Moffett
Homes for Black Children
1906 25th Street
Detroit, MI 48216-1440
RE: License #: CB820201177
Homes for Black Children
1906 25th Street
Detroit, MI 48216-1440
Dear Ms. Moffett:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 03/18/2019.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
from the American Heart Association or the American Red
Cross or other institution approved by the department.
One of six certification records reviewed, one adult member of the household did not
have current training in first aid. The last first aid training was in 2015.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS.
MiSACWIS
(Commitment
22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated
child welfare information system (MiSACWIS) which will be
the primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
The following information was not uploaded into MiSACWIS though noted in the
paper case record, the agency is not consistent with uploading information:
 Medical passports
 Unannounced home visits
 Foster parent training
 Updated service plans
 69b
 Family team meetings
 Parent agency treatment plans
 Foster care referral for adoption planning
 Adoptive placement assessment addendum
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL 01/31/2018
4

3). Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements except
for the following:
DHHS Policy Unannounced Home Visit
FOM 722-6H –
Page 7
Foster care workers must make an unannounced home visit to
licensed foster parents/caregivers every quarter. This
unscheduled visit must be noted in the social work contacts of
the service plan.
Four out of six case records reviewed were deficient with unannounced home visits
in the updated service plan reports. It is noted that monthly scheduled visits
occurred and the agency was able to provide written documentation that the
unannounced home visits occurred but not uploaded into MiSACWIS.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings
FOM 722-6B -
page 2
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
• Case service plan development,
• permanency goal changes,
• placement preservation/disruption
• permanency planning at six months in care annual transition
planning for youth every six months from age 16 until case
closure
• 90 - day discharge planning for youth
• Case closure
Three out of six case records reviewed did not have documentation of an FTM prior
to the service plans being held. One case record did not have a FTM for the child
and two were not uploaded into MiSACWIS.
DHHS Policy P e r s onnel Training.
SRM 200
All personnel, contractors, vendors and external auditors who
have access to CW – CHRI are required to complete security
awareness training (SAT). Training will be available on the
Learning management System (LMS) for MDHHS personnel
and contractors with access to this system.
5

SAT is required to be taken within six months of being in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all personnel with CHRI
access completes the SAT. DCWL consultants will monitor
completion of SAT as part of the annual licensing audit.
CI-182a was released to the field in December of 2016
advising all current employees with access to CHRI to
complete SAT training no later than 02/10/2017. All other
employees hired after December of 2016 were required to
complete SAT according to the policy.
There were eight employees with access to criminal record history information
(CHRI) since the last inspection. Based on the LMS transcript for employees, all
eight employees was found to not have completed the SAT training. The employees
took the specific training MDHHS Security Training on April 7, 2017 oppose to
Fingerprint Security Awareness Training.
DHHS Policy F o s t e r c a re – Parent agency Treatment Plan and Service
FOM 722 – 8C A greement.
Signature: when completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate including those of parent(s) guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHHS office designee.
Two out of six case records reviewed, two were missing the signatures and the
dates for the foster parents on the PATP.
6

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a CAP on 02/02/2018 for the Renewal Inspection that
was completed on 01/31/2018. The CAP was approved on 02/02/2018. The
agency was in non-compliance with the following violations:
R400.12306 (4) Application request
R400.12324 (8) Reevaluation
R400.12405 (3, a) Change of placement
R400. 12418 (2, b) Development of service plans
R400.12418 (3) Development of service plans
ISEP – 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22)
The agency affectively addressed the citations noted in the renewal inspection of
2018 as there was only one repeat violation noted during this interim inspection.
DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS ADDRESSED:
Safety Alert #1:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Other concerns reported by the foster parent: There was only 1 unannounced home
visit in 2018.
Foster parent reported that she has not received payment for almost 3 months
Resolution: Homes for Black Children (HFBC) foster care specialist recorded four
unannounced home visits in MiSACWIS 4/9/18, 5/7/18, 9/7/18 and 10/17/18.
Foster child came into care on 2/17/17. Payment was unauthorized by the State until
5/16/17 (three months).
7

This answer was not satisfactory by the consultant. The agency will submit a corrective
action plan due to a violation of their contract. PAFC 19 – 50001 Placing Agency Foster
Care states when the contractors’ financial records reveal that payment for a child has
not been provided by MDHHS within 30 days of receiving all necessary documentation,
the contractor will seek payment resolution by contacting the direct supervisor of the
assigned MDHHS worker in writing. Any concerns over a payment authorization or
issuance that cannot be resolved within 30 days of the written notice must be reported
to the MDHHS County Director for immediate resolution. The contractor will apprise
MDHHS office of Child Welfare Services and support of any ongoing, unresolved
payment concerns.
Safety Alert #2:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #3:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #4:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #5:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #6:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #7:
Concern: Caregiver reported that the adoption process has taken a long time (well over
a year or so) and she has had to report various steps in the process such as
fingerprinting.
8

The caregiver reported that there have been no unannounced visits to the home.
Resolution: The caregiver was referred to HFBC for adoption services in 02/2017. She
has been slow in submitting required documentation such as adoption application,
medicals, legal documents and local clearances. The caregiver after many set
deadlines, meetings and other follow-ups submitted her adoption application on
2/17/2018. The application was incomplete. Follow up was required in order to obtain
information regarding references. The adoption was delayed one year by the caregiver.
There are court reports, adoption quarterlies, child assessment addendum that has
addressed these barriers to adoption. A deadline letter dated March 8, 2018 was sent
to the caregiver.
There were three unannounced visit attempts made. Dates were April 30, 2018, July
17, 2018, and September 12, 2018. For all attempts no one was home or no one
answered the door. The foster care specialist recorded these attempts in MiSACWIS.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Homes for Black Children
continue on a regular license.
03/21/2019
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 22, 2019
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
